case_vignette: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
correct_ans: ct scan of head with contrast

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble breathing through my nose for a month and getting severe nosebleeds for about two weeks.
Are you currently taking any medications or have any significant medical history?
I have asthma and use an inhaler for it.
Do you have a history of bleeding disorders in your family?
No, I don't have a history of bleeding disorders in my family.
Have you noticed any unusual bruises or joint pain?
No, I haven't had any unusual bruises or joint pain.
Have you experienced any unintentional weight loss or fatigue recently?
No, I haven't experienced any unintentional weight loss or fatigue.
**Final Diagnosis:** Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
